{{also|haar|hår}} ==English== {{wikipedia}} ===Proper noun=== {{en-proper noun}} # A [[municipality]] near Munich, Germany. ===See also=== * {{l|en|Haar matrix}} * {{l|en|Haar sequence}} * {{l|en|Haar system}} * {{l|en|Haar transform}} * {{l|en|Haar wavelet}} ===Anagrams=== * {{anagrams|en|a=aahr|Hara}} ---- ==German== ===Etymology=== From {{etyl|goh|de}} {{m|goh|hār}}, from {{etyl|gem-pro|de}} {{m|gem-pro|*hērą}}, from {{etyl|ine-pro|de}} {{m|ine-pro|*keres-||rough hair, bristle}}. Compare {{cog|nl|haar}}, {{cog|fy|hier}}, {{cog|en|hair}}, {{cog|da|hår}}. ===Pronunciation=== * {{IPA|de|/haːɐ̯/}} {{a|standard}} * {{IPA|de|/haː/}} {{a|widespread, especially northern and central Germany}} * {{audio|de|De-Haar.ogg|audio}} * {{audio|de|De-at-Haar.ogg|audio (Austria)}} * {{rhymes|de|aːɐ̯}} ===Noun=== {{de-noun|n|Haars|gen2=Haares|Haare|Härchen}} # [[hair]] ====Usage notes==== When referring to a person's hair collectively, the singular may be used with no article, as is common in English: ''Sie hat graues Haar.'' – "She has grey hair." However in German, unlike English, it is more common to use the plural: ''Sie hat graue Haare.'' When referring to an individual hair, the indefinite article is used: ''Sie hat ein graues Haar.'' – "She has a (single) grey hair". ====Declension==== {{de-decl-noun-n|(e)s|e}} ====Derived terms==== * {{l|de|Barthaar}} * {{l|de|haarartig}} * {{l|de|Haaresbreite}} * {{l|de|Haar in der Suppe}} * {{l|de|Haarfarbe}} * {{l|de|Haarfärbung}} * {{l|de|haargenau}} * {{l|de|Haarshampoo}} * {{l|de|Haarspray}} * {{l|de|haarsträubend}} * {{l|de|haarähnlich}} * {{l|de|Haartönung}} * {{l|de|Haarwaschmittel}} * {{l|de|Schamhaar}} * {{l|de|Schnurrhaar}} ===See also=== * {{l|de|Haut}} ---- ==Pennsylvania German== ===Etymology=== From {{inh|pdc|goh|hār}}, from {{inh|pdc|gem-pro|*hērą}}.
